Think again.

Thereâ€™s a common misconception that AI always equals automation. This assumption often holds businesses and individuals back from exploring what AI can truly offer.

posts.name:
Adam Boggs
Adam Boggs
posts.content:
Heading off to Vegas today. Its "Let's SKO" Season!!! 
Being a Business Artist means integrating the principles of creativity, storytelling, and human connection into the core of our sales and business practices.

You don't become a better and more fulfilled sales person just by gaining years of experience. Like a great artist, a great seller gets better by trying new approaches, crafting new solutions, analyzing what works (and what doesn't), for them and for others and staying deeply curious about the world around you and in your customer's business.

The world doesn't need more coverbands or more clones of others.

If you give Christoper Nolan, Wes Anderson, Steven Spielberg all the same move script (just words on a page), you will get three totally different movies, all great and all in their style that works for them and their audiences.

Finding your own style and being able to "play jazz" in sales isn't a skill you acquire overnight, its a habit you cultivate.  It takes a tremendous amount of skill, knowledge and preparation of course, but then also a willingness to explore, get into a flow, improvise and adapt.

comments.commentText: Best content yetâ€¦just like practicing piano you keep playing and playing until one day you wake up and its music!
PJ Scott love that reference! And so true
I remember that stage shuffle dance at the beginning of the video from way back in business school Adam Boggs . Congrats on the book!
Chetan Maddipatla thank you! The dancing up and on to stage always gets me in the zone, regardless of my age;)

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this perspective! Embracing creativity in sales truly sets us apart. Excited to see how this SKO sparks new ideas! ğŸ¨âœ¨

posts.name:
Lucas Wilson
Lucas Wilson
posts.content:
The greatest threat to progress is distraction.

In scaling a team, a department, or even an entire company, opportunitiesâ€”both known and unknownâ€”can feel endless. But endless opportunities come with an endless risk: losing focus.

Iâ€™m often asked for the one piece of advice Iâ€™d give to leaders navigating this complexity. My answer is simple: Prioritize and execute.

1ï¸âƒ£ Define the mission. Ensure itâ€™s crystal clear and visible to everyone. A team that understands the â€œwhyâ€ behind the work will naturally align their efforts.
2ï¸âƒ£ Prioritize relentlessly. Every task must tie directly to the mission. If it doesnâ€™t, itâ€™s a distraction.
3ï¸âƒ£ Execute with accountability. The highest standards of ownership and follow-through will not only drive results but will also build trust and momentum.

When you hold yourselfâ€”and your teamâ€”to these principles, you create a culture of clarity and progress. The results? Meaningful growth, better service for your customers, and a business that thrives.

 How do you prioritize and execute in your leadership? What strategies have worked for you? Letâ€™s keep the conversation goingâ€”drop your thoughts below!
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Defining clear missions truly empowers teams. I prioritize by aligning tasks with strategic goals for better focus. What about others?

posts.name:
Yash J.
Yash J.
posts.content:
"Fail Faster"â€”A Philosophy That Redefines Success!

â€œFailure is a great teacher, and if youâ€™re open to it, every mistake has a lesson to offer.â€ This quote by Oprah Winfrey resonates deeply with me and aligns with the lessons I took fromâ€™s The Diary of a CEO. One of the biggest takeaways? The power of failing faster.

As a founder, Iâ€™ve realized that startups thrive on experimentation. Ideas are easy; itâ€™s the implementation and lessons from failure that truly drive innovation. Inspired by Stevenâ€™s insights, Iâ€™ve embraced the belief that failure isnâ€™t a setbackâ€”itâ€™s a step forward.

Letâ€™s take inspiration from, a company that has epitomized the Kaizen Philosophyâ€”a culture of continuous improvement. Toyota introduced small, incremental changes in its manufacturing processes, encouraging employees to experiment and make mistakes. This culture of learning through failure and constant refinement has kept Toyota at the top of the global car market for decades.

In startups, we need the same mindset. Bureaucracy between ideas and implementation kills momentum. If you donâ€™t allow yourself or your team the freedom to fail, you risk becoming rigid and stopping innovation altogether. Failure allows you to discover what doesnâ€™t work, clearing the path to strategies that canâ€™t fail.

"Fail Faster" isnâ€™t about recklessness; itâ€™s about learning quickly, pivoting dynamically, and iterating with purpose. Itâ€™s about trusting your team to take bold steps, knowing that even in failure, theyâ€™re moving forward.

At Train Rex, we live by this philosophy. Every marketing campaign, product feature, or user strategy is an experiment. Some succeed, many fail, but all teach us something valuable. Because when failure is embraced, growth becomes unstoppable.

Whatâ€™s your take on this? Are you experimenting enough to uncover your next big breakthrough?

comments.commentText: Failing faster is like a crash course in learning. I've found my best solutions after a stumble!
Agreed, Biggest breakthroughs often stem from what we learned in moments of failure.

posts.commentAdded: Embracing failure is essential for growth! Its inspiring to see how you foster a culture of experimentation at Train Rex. Keep pushing boundaries! ğŸš€

From fearing math to teaching it with passion! 
It's incredible to see how far we've come today, I'm not only overcoming my own fear of numbers, but also helping my students embrace the magic of mathematics in a fun and engaging way.
In this classroom, weâ€™re turning learning into a celebration!  With a hands-on activity focusing on perimeter, the kids are visualizing math in ways that make the abstract feel real and exciting.
By making math interactive and enjoyable, we're breaking down barriers and showing that math doesn't have to be scaryâ€”it can be fun, creative, and full of possibilities! A huge thank you to thefor teaching me that math is a language and that visualizing it is key to truly understanding it. I have always looked up to you guys for your wisdom and vision in transforming the way we think about math.
Here's to fostering a love for learning, one equation at a time!

Leadership isnâ€™t just about staying focused and sticking to plans.

Itâ€™s about understanding how emotions shape your decisions.

Emotions like stress, frustration, or fear can cloud judgment and affect productivity.

Recognizing these feelings is the first step in mastering self-discipline and becoming a stronger leader.

4ï¸âƒ£ Embrace emotional growth by understanding your emotions; it builds discipline and sharpens empathetic leadership.
